text: Signal integration and NF-kappa B translocation [ see comments ]

Adhesion molecules that tether circulating leukocytes to endothelial cells may also transduce or modulate outside-in signals for cellular activation , providing an initial regulatory point in the inflammatory response .

Adhesion of human monocytes to <extra_id_0> P-selectin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , the most rapidly expressed endothelial tethering factor , increased the secretion of <extra_id_0> monocyte chemotactic protein-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> MCP-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) and <extra_id_0> tumor necrosis factor-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) by the leukocytes when they were stimulated with platelet - activating factor .

text: These results demonstrate that <extra_id_0> P-selectin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , through its ligands on monocytes , may locally regulate cytokine secretion in inflamed tissues .
